title.narrative: Towards sustainable reform: promoting freedom of religion or belief in Armenia

description.narrative: The intended project objectives are as follows: 1. To advance FoRB in Armenia through regular policy work, advocacy efforts and strengthening capacities of religious or belief organizations. 2. To address the issue of teaching religion in schools via research, policy dialogue with the MoESCS (Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport), and building credible alternative options for opt-outs. 3. To contribute to the improvement of the quality and professionalism of media publications on issues of tolerance and diversity. The objectives set in the project were mostly met, some activities are not yet implemented and some actions need further work, more time and efforts to be achieved. However, with respect to certain activities, as a result of advocacy work, even better results are achieved than the project initially planned. Objective 1 In order to reach the objective 1 and the outputs set therein, a forum for discussions around issues of FoRB in Armenian and facilitated meetings with ethnic and religious communities continued to be held at the premises of EPF and beyond. This allowed for existing problems and matters of concern for these communities to be voiced, and be integrated into EPF’s policy and advocacy work. On November 4, 2019, Discussion of the Draft Law of the Republic of Armenia “On Ensuring Equality” was held at EPF with the participation of members from Seventh-day Adventist Church, Baha'i community, Armenian Evangelical Church, Assyrian community, local and international organizations (IOs). During the meeting, manifestations of discrimination in Armenia were discussed with participants, the Draft Law on Equality, Justification of the Necessity of the Draft Law, main provisions, Regulations, gaps and concerns were presented by EPF and a discussion followed. During the discussion, the notes of EPF’s annual FoRB conference session on conflicting rights have been used, which proved its crucial importance. EPF believes that through such and subsequent activities it builds the capacities of religious or belief organizations and contributes to the atmosphere of solidarity and tolerance between various minority groups. On November 19, EPF was invited to hold a session on fundamental human rights and freedoms, minority rights and child rights by Yezidi Center for Human Rights. During the meeting, the director of NGO highlighted the role of EPF in protecting the rights of national minorities in Armenia, and in mainstreaming Yezidi issues in particular, as well as expressed willingness to support the further activities of EPF with regard to Yezidi children. Isabella and Nikolay of EPF introduced the concepts of human rights and child rights with a focus on respective national instruments, the Constitution, and initiated a discussion with children, aimed at empowering them by addressing their concerns, interests and needs. On January 23, 2020, a small three-way meeting with activists from the Yezidi community, a Pastor and lawyer at Word of Life Church Armenia, and EPF took place at EPF’s premises. The meeting was initiated by EPF to discuss the developments of the case of a police officer in Armenia who was dismissed from his job for being a member of a religious organization, to exchange contacts and information on recent developments regarding FoRB and other emerging human rights issues in Armenia. Risks of becoming a tool of political speculation, the need for establishing extrajudicial mechanisms to hold people accountable for discriminatory behaviour, the process of constitutional amendments, and so-assumed problematic parts of the Istanbul Convention (according to several religious organizations) have been discussed and explained during the meeting. On February 21, 2020, a discussion around rights and issues of national minorities was held at EPF premises. EPF’s partner human rights organizations, representatives of national minorities, foreign missions in Armenia, and the EU Delegation to Armenia took part in the discussion. The aim of the meeting was to discuss problems within the national minority communities. EPF undertook the responsibility to initiate a meeting with the PM’s Office and address any raising problem accordingly, while international partners expressed willingness to engage and support the process as needed. Following the discussion, EPF engaged with several MPs in this regard and held a meeting with the PM Office on March 9, 2020. As the state of emergency emerged due to COVID-19, EPF was unable to hold regular offline meetings with ethnic and religious communities. However, on April 10, EPF communicated with its beneficiaries to explore their needs and understand if any additional activities are required by EPF to ease the situation, as well as provided EPF staff phone numbers for any emergency where EPF’s involvement and support would be required. EPF received positive feedback from several organizations, including Jehovah’s Witnesses, Seventh-day Adventist Church, Evangelical Church, who mentioned that despite the new circumstances that have created inconveniences, thanks to new technologies, they can hold the religious gatherings. EPF held a series of discussions with Georgia-based partner Tolerance and Diversity Institute (TDI), but given the new circumstances, EPF had to cancel its preparation work for the annual FoRB Conference in Tbilisi, which was initially planned to be held at the end of May 2020. At the beginning of the next reporting period, EPF will publicize the report prepared after the 2019 annual conference on Contemporary Issues of FoRB in Armenia, Georgia, and beyond, which touches upon legal, practical and academic materials and issues on FoRB. EPF remains the main organization in Armenia devoted to protecting FoRB, and the leading organization on the advocacy of Equality Law. During the reporting period, EPF contributed to public discussions and provided recommendations outlining anti-discrimination and freedom of religion-related issues, proposed modifications of Human Rights Action Plan (HRAP) 2019, submitted and initiated discussions on aforementioned issues for HRAP 2020-2022, made recommendations ahead of the 11th EU-Armenia Human Rights Dialogue, provided its contribution on FoRB, the Right of the Child to Education, to Freedom of Thought, Conscience and Religion, Violence against Children, Anti-Discrimination (Equality Law), Draft Law on National Minorities, Judiciary reforms, and amendments to the Law on Non-Governmental Organizations, as well as made an individual submission to the Human Rights Council Universal Periodic Review (UPR) of Armenia during its 35th session. At the time of writing, several major achievements have been registered in this regard. In particular, the restrictions on employment in the law of 04.04.2020 and 01.01.2022 on the Rescue Service, the law of 28.05.2020 - 01.01.2022 and 01.01.2022 on Penitentiary Service, the law of 01․01․2022 on Compulsory Enforcement Service, the law of 02.05.2020 on Public Service of the Republic of Armenia no longer prohibit the employment of members of religious organizations, which is a major achievement in terms of tackling institutional discrimination in Armenia. Such restriction for employment still exists in RA Law on Service in the National Security Bodies and RA Law on Service in Police. It is noteworthy, however, that on February 18, 2020, Armenia’s Constitutional Court declared the religious ban for police officers unlawful and unconstitutional. Objective 2 To find a credible mechanism to opt-out the History of Armenian Apostolic Church (AACh) school subject, EPF had earlier initiated Papers on FoRB and Education. In the reporting period, the policy papers, which explored the possibilities of legal ways to opt-out the subject, address the issue of teaching religion in schools, and presented recommendations focused on FoRB and education issues and were presented to the MoESCS’s consideration during public discussions and private meetings. While the earlier exchange of experiences took place with EPF’s Georgia-based partner TDI, during the reporting period, as the MoESCS initiated discussions over new public education standards, EPF got involved in discussions both on general public education standards, as well as subject-related new standards’ meetings. On October 8, 2019, EPF took part in a discussion of new subject-related education standards for school subjects History of Armenia and the History of AACh, where it raised its concerns over violation of FoRB due to the subject History of AACh and presented its recommendations deriving from Policy Papers. EPF further followed up with the Ministry and sent its written recommendations. On October 8, 2019, EPF took part in two other meetings at the premises of MoESCS and discussed the school subjects on human rights and media literacy. In these meetings, the draft state of the standard of general education developed by the working group was discussed in detail, which defines the competencies of the graduates of the main secondary education program, the expected final results of education, the minimum and maximum volumes of educational workload, and the 4 main components of the content of general education: knowledge, skill, attitude, value system. As EPF and partner organizations had been actively taking part in the HRAP 2020-22 discussions, an action on making the subject alternative had been added in the Action Plan. In November 2019, protests emerged in Armenia demanding for the resignation of the Minister of Education, linked with the new bill that the Ministry proposed, which would make the study of the Armenian language, literature, and history not mandatory for students of the non-humanitarian faculties of the universities and over the subject of the History of AACh being taken out from schools. EPF’s ongoing private discussions with the Ministry focus over the possibility and Ministry’s intention to take out the History of AACh from school curricula completely and integrating sections from the subject into other school subjects, such as the History of Armenia and Sociology. Further public and private discussions with the Ministry are planned to be held in June 2020, and the new standards, outlining that the History of AACh is to be opted out, leaving sections regarding the history of the church integrated into other subjects will be discussed. Objective 3 Several activities envisaged in the project have been successfully implemented to contribute to the improvement of the quality and professionalism of media publications on issues of FoRB, tolerance and diversity by increasing sensitivity of Armenian mass media in their coverage of issues of religious freedom and diversity. Through the religions.am website, in cooperation with Collaboration for Democracy Union (CDU), EPF has been undertaking efforts to raise the level of people's awareness on FoRB and related issues. During the reporting period, the website posted a total of 25 articles in Armenian, 12 articles in English, 160 and 333 materials in Press Review section from Armenian and Russian-language media, respectfully, and 9 photo-materials were posted. EPF’s partner CDU has had problems with registering statistics on the website as the website crashed in November, and google analytics did not record the data. However, during the second half of the reporting year, CDU actively shared the website materials on social media, with many likes and shares followed. Due to the political changes in the country on the one hand, and COVID-19 epidemic, on the other hand, religious issues have not enjoyed as much public interest as during the previous year, and more informative articles on religion, as well as interviews with specific and bold statements on the topic, gained popularity. EPF started the preparation for training with journalists, in particular, with media outlet managers, editors and decision-makers on FoRB and anti-discrimination to be held in March 2020. However, the state of emergency and the pandemic caused the public interest to shift to other health and political-related issues, and the event and this component have been postponed. The topic will reach its peak in gaining public interest once the Draft Law on Equality is brought before the NA, and EPF will undertake extensive work with journalists in this regard. The Annual Media Award Ceremony for the best media coverage on the topic of tolerance towards the religious and national minorities was planned to be held on March 26, 2020. However, the invitations had to be called back and the event was postponed as the pandemic-related situation emerged. The Media Awards are organized with the purpose to encourage balanced and delicate media reporting on tolerance, peaceful coexistence and diversity in Armenia which will promote the development of a tolerant and respectful attitude of the society towards minority communities. The winners this year were selected by a professional jury which reviewed media pieces published from 1 February 2019, to 5 March 2020. This year 34 materials were submitted for consideration, and a total of 9 authors from different media outlets in Armenia were awarded for encouraging prize, special prize, and six applicants awarded 1st to 3rd prizes. For raising visibility about the activity and promote the materials that got prizes, EPF recorded a video with the winning authors, jury members, the Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Kingdom of the Netherlands to Georgia and Armenia Maaike van Koldam, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Bulgaria to the Republic of Armenia Maria Pavlova Tzotzorkova-Kaymaktchieva, and Representative of the UNHCR in Yerevan Anna-Carin Öst, who all delivered messages to promote tolerance, coexistence and diversity. The video is planned to air on EPF’s Facebook page and Youtube channel on June 12, 2020. The project also allowed EPF to effectively engage in the anti-discrimination policy advocacy through meetings with MoJ, CSOs, making recommendations to these and other stakeholders and providing public speeches at various platforms. During the reporting period, EPF has also led the discussions among stakeholders and brought the draft Equality Law, its relevance and importance to the attention of international partners, civil society organizations and government partners. On October 7, 2019, EPF co-organized a discussion on the Draft Law together with the RA Ministry of Justice, where the Deputy Minister mentioned that the Government is pushing for a broader human rights agenda, and the adoption of the Equality Law is only a part of this broader agenda. Several recommendations made by OSCE/ODIHR, as well as EPF and civil society, have already been met by the MoJ. As the Interim Opinion mentions, there was a need for certain revisions and clarifications regarding concepts and definitions used in the Draft, which have already been modified by the Ministry. Important changes have been done in the Draft regarding legal and judicial procedural parts, which can provide effective protection of rights in proceedings. The matter of discriminatory provisions and clauses in several laws against followers of a religious organization (ie, the Law on Service in Police, the Law on Penitentiary Service, etc.) that do not apply to members of the AACh at the time of employment has been raised during the meeting by EPF. The Deputy MoJ mentioned in this regard, that there are some ongoing processes, and that it might be a separate concern that needs to be addressed. As the next paragraph uncovers, most of these problems have already been addressed in the reporting period. On January 27, 2020, EPF held another meeting with CSOs and IOs in Armenia intending to update each other on the progress of the Draft Law on Equality, discuss ongoing projects in the field of non-discrimination, share information and consolidate efforts by various local and IOs. Action points have been made by the end of the meeting for EPF to update all partners involved on developments and initiate further discussions, to follow and participate in public discussion planned at the National Assembly on hate speech, and for foreign missions and IOs in Armenia to follow-up on the adoption of Equality Law when they meet relevant authorities. On April 22, 2020, as the state of emergency due to the spread of COVID-19 had already emerged, EPF organized an online discussion on the progress and amendments of Draft Law “On Ensuring Equality”. EPF used its anti-discrimination-focused mailing list (ad@epfound.am) to have the participation of all interested partners and held an intensive and detailed meeting, where matters and timelines regarding the process of adoption, observations of the Office of the PM, tactical changes, distribution of the burden of proof, observations and recommendations of CSOs have been discussed with partner organizations, MoJ, MPs of NA’s Standing Committee on Human Rights, and Ombudsman’s Office. To EPF’s knowledge, the Draft Law will be brought to NA during its autumn sessions in 2020. Throughout all the activities, EPF has ensured the visibility and ownership of the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands through banners, disclaimers, announcements, media materials, etc., during formal and informal events.

The project addresses the issues of freedom of religion or belief in the Republic of Armenia with a focus on the new draft law on Freedom of Conscience and Religious Organizations, violations of FoRB of children and parents in public education as well as enhancing the implementation of the soon to be adopted law on Equality. As a part of the project an informal forum for discussions will be established for religious or belief communities, several conferences tackling FoRB issues in Armenia and Georgia will be conducted; trainings and annual media award for journalists will be performed, journalists and media outlets will be further sensitized on the issues of FoRB. EPF will work with the Office of Human Rights Defender and Equality body on concrete cases of violations of FoRB in Armenia in order to create positive precedents and encourage others to use this mechanism for better human rights protection. Stronger networks of religious organizations will be supported which will jointly advocate for improvements of the law. In the sphere of education, EPF will explore options for opt-outs and communicate these to the school councils and religious communities.

The annual analytical narrative progress report of the project Towards sustainable reform: promoting freedom of religion or belief in Armenia covers the reporting period of June 1, 2019- May 31, 2020.
